fields.description:
We have a handful of projects that are visible to all of our employees that shouldn't be visible to them. 

These repos do not have "Public Access" enabled, nor do they have any groups added to "Group Access". Most of these projects just have a couple of users specified in the "Project Permissions > User Access", so I would expect these projects to only show up on these users' Projects page.

I don't see any common denominator between these projects as to why their permissions are weird. For the 95% of our other projects, the permissions seem to be working fine.
fields.summary: Users can see Projects and Repos they don't have permissions to.

fields.description:
I am currently using Stash 2.9.4. I wanted to configure the pull request notification as mentioned in this https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Notifications link.
Currently Users are not receiving email notifications for pull requests.
Where can I configure the same?

Regards,
Pawan
fields.summary: Pull request notifications
Output 400 rather than 500 error when Stash can't recognize/parse JSON objects properly

fields.description:
It'd be nice if there was some way to mark that I have approved an individual file of a pull request.  This doesn't need to be visible to everyone involved in the request; just to the user doing the approval. 

I'd like this feature because there are times when pull requests require changes (get denied) and then require approval again. Instead of having to remember what files or chunks of data have been approved I'd like to be able to mark files as "approved."
fields.summary: Individual File Approval

fields.description: I clicked on the button to decline a pull request, and it was immediately merged. The activity stream for the pull request shows that it was declined, and then merged. I definitely did not want to merge it, and this is even stranger because once you've declined a pull request, the button to merge disappears.
fields.summary: Denying pull request can trigger merge
startup and shutdown errors if stash.home system property is not set

fields.description:
The pull request diff viewer allows me to add comments to individual lines of code. If I add a mention to the comment, that person will receive a notification email. This is great, but one thing is missing:
 
If I am commenting on a line of the code and that line is an added or deleted line and the developer who made that change is not the same as the developer who submitted the pull request, I want a mention of that developer to be in the comment edit box when I first create the comment. 

The attached example is what I expect to happen assuming "e18976" was the developer who modified line 24 of the file.
 
(I still need blame info for each line, but this comment change is more important because it will make mixed code reviews work well)



Alternatively, a checkbox or something which will "copy committers" which would either harvest the ID of the person(s) involved in the selected lines and inject into the regular @ style mention, or harvest the email address from the blame information and inject them as part of the notification object assembly.  That might be a simpler way to handle this without having to pre-fill data into comment box.
fields.summary: notification enhancement for mentions in pull request diff viewer

fields.description:
This bug was reported in SubGit issue tracker: [SG-72|http://issues.tmatesoft.com/issue/SG-72].

When Git-SVN mirror is enabled for a Git repository via SVN Mirror Add-on, user is not able to create new Git branches via Stash UI.

When Stash creates a new Git branch, it doesn't trigger {{pre-receive}} hook and doesn't raise any events. As result SubGit plugin has no information on performed action. Next time the plugin synchronizes Git repository with Subversion server, it deletes Git branch since its SVN counterpart is missing in the latest revision.

As a workaround Stash user has to create a branch in his local repository and then push that branch back to Stash:
{code}
git push <origin> <branch>
{code}
We would appreciate if Stash could somehow notify our plugin on new branch creation when user adds a branch via Stash UI.

Thank you in advance,
Semyon
fields.summary: No hooks are triggered when user creates Git branch via Stash UI

fields.description:
This bug was reported in SubGit issue tracker: [SG-61|http://issues.tmatesoft.com/issue/SG-61].

When Git-SVN mirror is enabled for a Git repository via [SVN Mirror Add-on|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/org.tmatesoft.subgit.stash-svn-importer], "delete source branch" option is not respected while merging pull requests.

When Stash deletes a source branch, it raises no events and provides no information on deleted branch via {{GitPullRequestMergeRequestedEvent}}. As result SubGit plugin has no information on performed action. Next time the plugin synchronizes Git repository with Subversion server, it resurrects deleted Git branch since its SVN counterpart still presents in the latest revision.

As a workaround Stash user has to delete source branch manually as soon as pull request is merged:
{code}
git push <origin> --delete <branch>
{code}
We would appreciate if Stash could somehow notify our plugin on source branch deletion when user merges pull request.

Thank you in advance,
Semyon
fields.summary: No hooks are triggered on pull request source branch deletion

fields.description: It would be useful if branch "behind / ahead" status was displayed on a pull request's page (as well as the Pull Requests table). This would help remind authors to pull in the latest changes from the target branch, as well as alerting reviewers that the pull request may not have been tested against those changes.
fields.summary: Display branch "behind / ahead" status for pull requests

fields.description:
Stash allows uses to use Gravatar to display user profile images.

Can this be extended to allow an enterprise image library to be used?
fields.summary: Allow avatars to use enterprise image library

fields.description: When reviewing large pull requests, I'm often switching between files. When I'm just looking something up in a file, I haven't reviewed the whole file and would like it to remain 'unread' (bold). This way, I have a better overview of which files still need reviewing. It would, therefore, help if there is an option to manually mark a file as 'unread', similar to e-mail.
fields.summary: Manually mark file in pull request as unread

fields.description:
When there are multiple jenkins builds on a pull request for a commit and some of them are red then the indicator will stay red instead of changing to green when the last build is successful. The desired effect would be that the last build is the shown status and maybe an indication of how many builds in the history.

Example scenario:
2 builds. First failed and 2nd succeeded. It is displayed as: "1 Build failed <red exclamation icon>"
When you click on that for more information it opens a small window showing both builds.

Expected:
Displayed as: "2 Builds <green correct icon>"

Expected if the 1st succeeded but 2nd build failed:
Displayed as: "2 Builds <red exclamation icon>"

Desired:
The required successful builds should come into play here.
This indicator should be showing whether the pull request is in a state of being merged or not. So if the "required successful builds" are set to 3 then...

Scenario:
5 builds, 2 failed, last 3 successful:
"3 Builds (5) <green correct icon>"

5 builds, 1st, 3rd and 5th successful, rest failed:
"1 of 3 Builds (5) <red exclamation icon>"
fields.summary: Jenkins builds not updating status

fields.description:
We miss the reviewboard feature being able to see changesets based on different revisions of pull requests.

When reviewing and commenting pull requests there are often changes that have to be made. If the pull request is not small, then when the it is updated it's easy to miss things that have changed from previous revisions or to forget to check that problems commented on have been addressed.

I guess this feature is also closely related to:
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-4263
fields.summary: Pull request revisions

fields.description: We really enjoy the convenience of the Stash user interface but severely miss the ability to view diffs between arbitrary commits/branches in it.
fields.summary: Arbitrary diffing

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thanks to everyone for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Data Center.

We spend a significant amount of time determining our product investments in Bitbucket Data Center. Unfortunately, we are not planning to address this suggestion in the next 12 months. In the last year, we have resolved many of the highly voted suggestions like Reviewer groups, Pull request templates, capability to enable/disable source branch deletion on merging pull requests and our upcoming roadmap includes a number of other top voted suggestions, including repository archiving. Please check out our [public roadmap|https://www.atlassian.com/roadmap/data-center?product=bitbucket] for more details on the coming soon and future items.

I understand that this may be disappointing, but it’s important for us to be open, honest, and transparent with our customers. Product feedback is collected from many different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Cheers,
Imran Khan
Product Manager - Bitbucket Data Center & Server
{panel}
We miss the ability to inspect and update pull requests before actually publishing them to reviewers.

This is especially convenient when you have automatically added reviewers on a repository.

This is a feature that was much appreciated by developers when we where using ReviewBoard.
fields.summary: Pull request drafts

fields.description:
When viewing https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/ATLASSIAN/repos/crowd/diff/components/horde-web-app/src/main/java/com/atlassian/crowd/horde/applinks/LicensedApplinksService.java?until=000efa58e41d1d9927f6d8fd595d9f04fbc4a5f8&at=000efa58e41d1d9927f6d8fd595d9f04fbc4a5f8
the commit hash is populated in the Branch selector.

This breaks the Branches tab which tries to populate the base branch with a commit hash
fields.summary: Commit hash populated in Branch Selector when viewing source, breaks Branches tab

fields.description:
I would like to use HipChat to automatically display notifications to the team when there are new pull requests, etc. so that any interested parties can have a look.

I'm trying to get the team to stop adding everyone as a reviewer and only invite one or two people but this is quite difficult when people feel they have little visibility (or awareness) of pull requests. And trying to get people to manually post a message about a pull request doesn't work reliably either!

There is another HipChat plugin on the marketplace (Go2Group) but it is all-or-nothing when it comes to pull requests: you get a notification for a new pull request (in fact you get two notifications for this and one has an invalid link), comments, adding commits (called rescoping), and merging (which in turn rescopes all other open pull request and they all send a notification). Basically, it needs to be more fine grained to avoid people ignoring them as overload.

I'd also like to have it "mention" people when their comment is replied to (or when their pull request is commented on). Ideally, I'd like to be able to stop email notifications and get the same kind of thing in HipChat.
fields.summary: Improve HipChat integration

fields.description:
I am working on a stash plugin and find the developer toolbar, specifically, the FastDev feature, extremely useful.

In a clean, example plugin, created with {{atlas-create-stash-plugin}}, with stash version set to 2.9.4 in {{pom.xml}}, I do see the Developer Toolbar at the bottom when opening the page. See attachment "Screen Shot 2014-01-08 at 4.41.03 PM.png".

When using the most recent, non-specified version, stash 2.10.1, there is no Developer Toolbar.

How can this functionality be restored?

When I log into 2.10.1 as the admin user, I can see the FastDev (and other) plugins have been enabled.
fields.summary: atlas-debug with stash version 2.10.1 does not have Developer Toolbar

fields.description:
{quote}
[Per] our companies compliance requirements we must not allow to search our active directory groups for everybody because these group names contain informations of our customer names... and as we have many customers we have different customers where maybe one customer "A" may not like to see a customer "B" of us that is competetive to "A"...

Sadly EVERY user is able to create private repositories (although they do not have any permission to other repositories/projects) and thus is able to administer them and SEARCH Groups. 

Is there a way to do clever filtering? Like:

    If user is in group x he only can search for groups x-x
    or
    Only users in group x, y and z can search for group names
    or worse:
{quote}
fields.summary: Limit group search in private repos

fields.description: Currently, the 'Create Branch' screen can only create branches based on existing branches. Would be feasible to add the *Tags* compatibility, by that the developers can create branches from tags as well.
fields.summary: Create branch from a tag context should honour the base tag as selected

fields.description: Project keys restrict administrators to letters, numbers and underscores. Repository slugs, on the other hand, also allow hyphens. Project keys should do the same.
fields.summary: Support project keys with hyphens

fields.description:
As a Stash administrator, it'd be good to be able to avoid daily outages when performing Stash backups. The current backup client solution does not address this issue. 

Some enterprise customers might have a Stash instance as an important piece in their CI process plus a development team is distributed across different continents - situations in which you can't afford a long downtime.

Currently, the workaround as per the recommendation in the [Data recovery and backups|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Data+recovery+and+backups] document, involves shutting down Stash and using your own scripts to backup the database and filesystem - a [cold backup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Data+recovery+and+backups#Datarecoveryandbackups-cold].

Mentioning the [Data recovery and backups|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Data+recovery+and+backups] document:

{quote}
With either strategy, schedule the backup window so as to minimise the impact on Stash availability. You might consider checking the access logs to determine patterns of lowest usage to help with this.
{quote}
fields.summary: Backup Stash with zero downtime

rest-api-browser.min.js.

fields.description:
As explained in the issue JRA-35413, the json response given by Stash does not match the configured Base URL when hitting stashinstance/stash/rest/capabilities/navigation.

While trying to create a branche from JIRA, it results to a call to the wrong address within the user's browser. As [~rsmart] says [as designed for JIRA|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-35413?focusedCommentId=543914&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-543914]:
bq. The URL that create branch uses is given to it by stash (its baseURL in the json response at: stashinstance/rest/capabilities/navigation)

Here is my configuration:
* In the Stash 2.10 instance:
** Stash Base URL: https://full.stash.address.com/stash
* In the JIRA 6.1 instance, configured Stash Application Link:
** Application URL: http://localhost:7990/stash
** Display URL: https://full.stash.address.com/stash

When trying to create a branch from JIRA, the instance hit http://localhost:7990/stash/rest/capabilities/navigation, the JSON answer is:
{code:javascript}
{
    "create-branch":[{
            "href": "http://localhost:7990/stash/plugins/servlet/create-branch",
            "label": "Stash",
            "icon": "http://localhost:7990/stash/plugins/servlet/create-branch/icon.png",
            "tooltip": "",
            "lang": "en-GB",
            "weight":300
        }]
}
{code}


(i) After [~rsmart] comment [here|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-35413?focusedCommentId=543914&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-543914], it seems the JSON answer from the Stash instance should always be as configured in the Stash instance Base URL:
{code:javascript}"href": "https://full.stash.address.com/stash/plugins/servlet/create-branch"{code}
fields.summary: REST json response does not match the configured Base URL

fields.description:
How to reproduce:

1. Open pull request with at least two files
2. Add 3 draft comments in first file (don't post them)
3. Go to second file
4. Go back to the first file

Observation: Only latest comment (last added, placement doesn't matter to me) will be shown, others are lost :(

Critical as I just lost few comments.
fields.summary: Only one draft comment is saved in local storage per file

fields.description:
Customers might use a set of branches named as follows:

Development branch:
master

Release Branches:
release/aaa.1
release/aaa.2
release/aaa.3
release/bbb.1
release/bbb.2
release/bbb.3
release/ccc.1
release/ccc.2
release/ccc.3

Essentially - families of releases (aaa, bbb, ccc), with numbered iterations.

When auto-merge feature is turned on in Stash on this repo, a pull request to any numbered iteration of a given family attempts to auto-merge across all subsequent iterations of that release family. However, the auto-merge utility also auto-merges down to the Development branch automatically, and this is something they might like to control the merging on manually, and currently there is no way of turning off the Development branch auto-merge in the built-in Stash functionality.

To clarify - the automerge currently merges (using the branches above) in the following flow:
bbb.0 -> bbb.1 -> bbb.2 -> master

They might like it to automatically flow like:
bbb.0 -> bbb.1 -> bbb.2

With a subsequent manual merge (via pull request) from bbb.2 -> master.
fields.summary: Allow auto-merging specific branch/branches

fields.description:

They would like to be able to view the diffs for this file from Stash but it currently exceeds the limits of the tooling (warning is displayed that the diff is too large to render and provides the command to retrieve it manually).  Are there any plans to possibly improve the way diffs are rendered to allow viewing of diffs to this type of large file without going outside of Stash?  

The file in question is around 650KB and renders fine in Stash.  Haven't checked to see what the size of the diff it creates would be.
fields.summary: Improve the ability to render the diffs for larger files

fields.description:
Hi,

I'm currently attempting to develop a Stash Plugin that will contain my own versions of HttpAuthenticationHandler and HttpAuthenticationContext. I can supply more details about my intent, but I'm not sure if that's relevant.

However, after much head scratching, it does not appear that these interfaces are available in _2.8.4_. I have another ticket open [ https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/AMPS-1071 ] related the fact that the SDK doesn't let me create Stash plugins later than 2.8.4, although that's slightly moot since I am targeting 2.8.4.

To reproduce, create a simple plugin:

{{atlas-create-stash-plugin}}

then create stash-plugin-modules:

{{atlas-create-stash-plugin-module}}

Select '2', for Component Import. The interfaces are

{{com.atlassian.stash.auth.HttpAuthenticationHandler}}

and

{{com.atlassian.stash.auth.HttpAuthenticationContext}}

respectively.

This creates a atlassian-plugin.xml file with the following:

{code}
  <component-import key="applicationProperties" interface="com.atlassian.sal.api.ApplicationProperties"/>
  <component-import key="httpAuthenticationHandler" interface="com.atlassian.stash.auth.HttpAuthenticationHandler" filter=""/>
  <component-import key="httpAuthenticationContext" interface="com.atlassian.stash.auth.HttpAuthenticationContext" filter=""/>
{code}

and then attempt start the plugin with {{atlas-run --product stash}}.

The empty plugin "loads", to an extent, but reviewing the logs shows that it doesn't resolve correctly

{code}

2013-12-19 14:26:07,208 ERROR [Timer-1]  c.a.plugin.osgi.factory.OsgiPlugin Never resolved service '&httpAuthenticationHandler' for plugin 'com.example.privAuth.overloadHttpAuth' with filter (objectClass=com.atlassian.stash.auth.HttpAuthenticationHandler)
2013-12-19 14:26:07,208 ERROR [Timer-1]  c.a.plugin.osgi.factory.OsgiPlugin Never resolved service '&httpAuthenticationContext' for plugin 'com.example.privAuth.overloadHttpAuth' with filter (objectClass=com.atlassian.stash.auth.HttpAuthenticationContext)
2013-12-19 14:26:07,210 ERROR [Timer-1]  c.a.plugin.osgi.factory.OsgiPlugin Unable to start the plugin container for plugin com.example.privAuth.overloadHttpAuth

{code}

Actually importing those package libraries and attempting to use them in the custom {{.java}} file is not successful either.

The documentation does state that these formats are _in_beta_. See https://developer.atlassian.com/static/javadoc/stash/2.8.4/spi/reference/com/atlassian/stash/auth/HttpAuthenticationHandler.html :

"Please note that the HTTP authentication APIs are currently considered to be BETA and are expected to change slightly in future releases. Breaking API changes will be avoided where possible, but may happen."

If they have been changed, please update the documentation as soon as possible.
fields.summary: HttpAuthenticationHandler/HttpAuthenticationContext unavailable

fields.description:
{{getUsersWithPermission}} users {{UserService.findUsersByGroup}} to load the {{StashUsers}} for each group. It then calls {{getName()}} name on all of these users to get the usernames. Under the hood embedded crowd loads each user by name for the {{findUsersByGroup}} query if there are multiple directories and the user isn't in the first one. This can make {{getUsersWithPermission}} incredibly expensive (n+1 problem).

The {{LicenseService}} attempts to mitigate this by caching the licensed user count. However it maintains 5 separate caches requiring the licensed user count to be repopulated for each. The cache should be consolidated and repopulated in the background to minimise the impact on end users.

h1. Workaround

The current workaround is to reorder the directories to have the largest directory first. When doing this you should be mindful of STASH-3717 which can lead to users being locked out of Stash
fields.summary: Licensed user count cache should be repopulated in the background to avoid blocking request threads

fields.description:
We'd like the ability to prevent data loss from every occurring in our repositories, while still supporting administrative activities such as explicitly deleting a tag that should not have been made.

Ideally, it would be possible in Stash to forbid destructive git operations entirely -- forced pushes, branch deletions, tag deletions, etc -- while still offering an explicit interface for deleting/renaming branches/tags/etc by administratively approved users.
fields.summary: Built-in support for blocking branch and tag deletion without administrative approval.

fields.description:
One of the more significant frustrations we have with git is the ability to perform destructive changes to the central repository -- accidentally or intentionally.

It would be nice if Stash offered a write-only approach to repository history (unless specifically overridden by the administrator), whereby destructive commits were allowed, but actually could be reversed, eg, via the audit log.

This is a feature that TeamForge has: http://www.collab.net/products/teamforge/git-for-the-enterprise#tab5
fields.summary: Allow rolling back data-destructive commits

fields.description:
*Background*

We are currently evaluating whether we could replace Crucible by Stash and its Pull Request feature. So far, Stash's ability to create pull requests in combination with its Branching Model looks very promising.

However, we stumbled upon the following issue:

*Present Situation*

Currently, new commits to a branch (for instance, feature branch) that is involved in an open pull request (for instance, from that feature branch to the main development branch) are _automatically_ added to that open pull request.

*Feature Request*

It should be configurable whether new commits would be automatically added to an open pull request or not.

If not, Stash would not automatically add new commits to the open pull request but would put those commits into some queue (or something like that). From there, selected commits could be explicitly added to a new pull request. This would prevent that new aspects which might be introduced by further commits would "slip" into existing reviews although those aspects should be discussed in separate reviews.

*Rationale*

We have feature branches that typically live for a couple of days (up to one or even two weeks - they are created via Stories in JIRA Agile). At the same time, we encourage developers to push their daily changes every evening to enable reviewers to give swift feedback on that daily work. This again allows developers to incorporate important feedback as soon as possible (particularly, not only at the end of the Sprint).

Ideally, the reviewer would approve such an pull request early in the morning; thus, immediately. However, sometimes the review reveals weak spots and the developer would have to make smaller fixes. For such fixing commits, it is absolutely fine to be automatically added to the open pull request - because these commits affect aspects that are already part of the pull request. For comparison: In Crucible, the developer would explicitly add these commits to the ongoing review (via smart commits - how cool is that?).

Beyond that, frequently there are new commits that add new aspects, too - just because the story is not yet completed and thus being developed in the said feature branch and pull request, respectively. In this case, these commits should _not_ be automatically added to the open pull request. Instead, they should be addressed in a new pull request that would explicitly cover the new aspects. Again, for comparison: In Crucible, such new commits would be added to a new review but not the existing one.
fields.summary: Disable automatic adding of new commits to existing pull request

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – December 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Bitbucket Server team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-bug-fixing-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication. If you're really passionate about this suggestion, please comment with your case in detail and we'll reconsider. Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Imran Khan
Product Manager - Bitbucket Server and Data Center
{panel}

It would be nice to have a way to compare 2 versions of a document for a pull request.  This way people can comment on lines within the document.

I understand that this is primarily for code/text based reviews, but we would like to be able to use this workflow to handle document review as well
fields.summary: Document review in pull request (non-plaintext)

fields.description:
Repo:

1. Create a repo and add some revision history to it
2. Fork repo
3. Make changes to master branch on fork
4. Issue pull request from fork to upstream
5. In a local clone of fork reset --hard the head back to match upstream
6. Force push the local clone to the fork

At this point the fork and its upstream have identical heads and Stash marks the pull request as merged.  This isn't correct, all changes for the pull request were reverted out of the fork and thus nothing was merged.  Declined would be more appropriate.

Worse the pull request description still lists the commits and differences from the revoked commit objects.

This would make sense if the pull request was static at the point it was created but the general pull request process has been written to automatically add new commits to the source branch as such it should correctly handle commits being removed from the source branch and if the pull request ever ends up empty it should either decline, delete or just leave it open and empty.  Marking as merged seems like the only option that's actually wrong.
fields.summary: Mark pull request as declined instead of merged when force push reduces mergeable commits to zero

fields.description:
Gmail has begun making images safer by proxying them through Google internal servers.

Any Stash instance that is behind a firewall will not be visible to Gmail's servers, and therefore images will show up as broken within Gmail.

Potential solutions:
- embed images in the email (adds weight to emails)
- host images on a public CDN (not feasible for air-gapped customers)

h3. Workaround 
This issue is specifically about Google Gmail not being able to show images when a Stash instance is behind a firewall that Google's servers can't access. This is due to Google implementing an image proxy which means any images shown in Gmail are retrieved through Google's servers.

If you are a Google Apps customer there is an [Image URL Proxy Whitelist that can be configured in the Google Apps admin|https://support.google.com/a/answer/3299041?hl=en]. You (or your Google Apps administrator) can add your Stash server's URL to the whitelist which will mean your browser will talk to Stash directly to retrieve the images, so as long as your browser can access Stash then images should show in Gmail.
fields.summary: Firewalled images are broken in emails (Gmail)

fields.description: Currently the idle timeout for SSH sessions is currently controlled by {{plugin.ssh.command.timeout.idle}} which by default is set to 86400 seconds (1 day). This is fine when git clients use default SSH configuration which terminates SSH sessions on completion of the command but if users are using configurations such as those suggested in [speed-up-git-5x-to-50x|http://interrobeng.com/2013/08/25/speed-up-git-5x-to-50x/] the sessions will remain in memory. Over the coarse of the day this can build up and result in an OOME. The idle timeout (which is the timeout in which no packets have been sent in either direction) should be set much lower, most likely around 30 minutes
fields.summary: SSH idle timeout is too large resulting in OutOfMemoryError when clients fail to terminate the session

fields.description:
Stash does not invalidate session upon login. To reproduce, make sure you're logged out, delete the {{JSESSIONID}} cookie and open a page in Stash (not logged in) that creates a session (e.g. home link). A new {{JSESSIONID}} cookie will be generated and it _will not change_ upon login, which allows for session fixation attacks. Confirmed that re-using the cookie value in another browser results in using the same session - and user account.

Worth noting that Stash does not accept (to the best of my knowledge) any way of providing session ID other than the cookie, so this is not easily exploitable. Nevertheless it is against good practices to keep the same session after login.
fields.summary: Stash does not invalidate session upon login

fields.description:
Errors in documentation (Stash home directory // Stash installation directory)

Link: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Connecting+Stash+to+an+external+database

Download and install the JDBC driver

The JDBC drivers for MySQL are not bundled with Stash (due to licensing restrictions). You need to download and install the driver yourself.

    Download the MySQL Connector/J JDBC driver from the download site.
    Expand the downloaded zip/tar.gz file.
    Copy the mysql-connector-java-5.1.XX-bin.jar file from the extracted directory to your <Stash home directory> /lib directory (for Stash 2.1 or later).
    Stop Stash, on Windows, or on  Linux and Mac .
    Restart Stash, on Windows, or on Linux and Mac.



Error: <Stash home directory>
Correction: <Stash installation directory>

----------------------------

Link: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Stash+upgrade+guide

If you are using MySQL


Stash does not ship with the MySQL database driver.

You need to reinstall the driver in the new installation, or copy the previous driver from the old <Stash installation directory>/lib to the new <Stash home directory>/lib.



Error: <Stash home directory>
Correction: <Stash installation directory>
fields.summary: Errors in documentation

fields.description:
It would be very nice to be able to view your diffset while creating a pull request, similar to how the diffset is displayed when receiving/reviewing a pull request.

Kind regards,
Koen
fields.summary: Easier way to review PR while making it
Syntax highlight Rakefiles

fields.description:
As a repository admin, I want to ensure that a branch is not only fast-forward only but also does not contain merges, which enforces committers to this branch to rebase their work properly.

This helps to keep the commit history sane and reliable to work with using external automation tools. Otherwise, the possibility exists that existing changes are missed out by i.e. reporting tools that evaluate changes between two commits.

Additional acceptance criteria:
* The branch name(s) to which this applies can be specified using standard regular expressions

\\
This request shall enable the same functionality that is available in gitolite:
* http://gitolite.com/gitolite/g2/aac.html#mergecheck
fields.summary: Allow no-merges policy
Nothing.

fields.description:
As a repository admin I can restrict force-pushes in a more fine-grained manner by specifying which branches do or do not allow force-pushes.

This would allow for legitimate force-pushes in a feature branch while protecting the default branch.

Additional acceptance criteria:
* full regular expression syntax can be used to select branches
fields.summary: Disable force-push per branch, branch type or branch pattern

fields.description:
As a project or repo admin I can define a branch/tag naming scheme that is enforced so that only conforming branch or tag names can be created.

This could be in the form of an extension to the branching model, or possibly implemented as a plugin (this sentence was added by Roger Barnes)

Additional acceptance criteria:
* full regular expression syntax can be used for branch/tag names
fields.summary: Restrict addition of branches and tags by name

fields.description:
Hello,
I'm Francesco from Bticino.
We are trying the Stash product with an evaluation license in order to decide if adpot it or not in our company.
I've installed stash without any problem and I've also put it on https with success.
But now I get an error when trying to clone a git repository by using https protocol (ssh works fine). When I run "git clone" command on my client the system return to me this error:server certificate verification failed

Cloning into 'myhomeinternational'...
fatal: unable to access 'https://stashadmin@<nyurl>:8443/scm/myh/myhomeinternational.git/': server certificate verification failed. CAfile: /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt CRLfile: none
"
I'm sure I'm doing something wrong, but I don't know what!
Please. Can you help me to fix this error?

Thanks in advance.

Francesco

fields.description:
Now branch patterns work for a strange way — patters {{master\*\*}} did not match {{master-1.2/blablabla}} — you need to use {{master\*/\*\*}}.

Relative to docs patterns {{tags/}} and {{tags/**}} the same:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Branch+permission+patterns

It is too complicated to understand to to use that. Ant patterns is something like martians patterns.

Can you also support for simple old-school Perl Regular Expressions, that inlined into java.util.Pattern?
fields.summary: Support regular expressions in Branch Patterns

fields.description:
As of the [corresponding documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/Configuring+syntax+highlighting+for+file+extensions]:
bq. The configured file extensions and hashbangs for each language can be overridden in Stash 2.7 and above via the {{<STASH_HOME>/stash-config.properties}} file.

However in 2.9.4, overriding the default extensions do not work. 

*Steps to reproduce*
# Override index highlighting for {{html}} based on [the documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/Configuring+syntax+highlighting+for+file+extensions], specify python for example
# Restart Stash
# Add a {{.html}} file to one of the repositories, containing python code, another one with regular HTML
# Notice the highlighting not changing, HTML is highlighted properly, while Python content is also highlighted as HTML in the .html file
fields.summary: Overriding syntax highlighting default extensions does not work

fields.description:
Both force push and synchronize->discard for forks with fork syncing enabled (which I'm assuming is basically just a force push under the scenes anyway) are dangerous operations that can permanently alter the version history in unrecoverable ways and which don't show up in the commit log.

It would be useful if the occurrence of such an event and the user who performed either of the actions was listed in the audit log.

We had a problem recently with someone incorrectly discarding changes when resolving a fork sync issue and we have been unable to track down who performed it so we can talk through the impact that had and provide more training.
fields.summary: Force push and synchonize->discard should go in the audit log

fields.description:
*Update: Shipped in Bitbucket Server and Data Center 5.10* 

*Original request description*

One problem our developers are starting to have now that we've migrated to Stash is keeping on top of changes in repositories that we make use of but don't directly develop. Our deliverable projects are large and made up of multiple smaller component projects each with multiple repositories (it all adds up to hundreds of repositories in a final deliverable project).

It would be very useful to our developers if they could receive emails on changes being pushed to the server for certain parts of the code that are of especial interest to them. You already have the concept of watching a pull request, it would be nice if this could be extended to allow a user to watch:

1. A branch - See any pushes to that branch
 2. A repository - See any pushes to that repository on any branch
 3. A project - See any pushes to any branch of any repository in that project.

A REST API to add and remove yourself as a watcher would also be usefull so we can script setting up watch lists accross entire projects if need be.

While there are some plugins that allow this a lot of the time they require admin permissions to the module to allow you edit the plugins email settings to add and remove users. Watching should only require read permissions to a repository as it doesn't require making any changes.
fields.summary: Add the ability to watch projects, repositories and branches

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to list users to be automatically set up to watch a pull request that are not a reviewer.

The most common use of this would be to make sure a other developers who have worked on the changes see comments or so other people who need to know about an incoming change (but who don't have review authority) get notified about the request.
fields.summary: Add watchers to pull requests at creation time

fields.description:
For some users structure using a "\" or "/" or other symbols in project names.

This causes some problems with the quick search functionality as the slash ( / ) is used as separator between the project and repository names. In essence, this means that if we have a project named foo/bar and we want to search for it, the search feature will assume the project name is foo and the repository is bar.

Having a way to configure "special characters" in Project name would be useful a lot.
fields.summary: Configurable separators

fields.description:
Currently if PR has been declined, only email notification sent out and there is no any notifications about the declined PR in the 'My pull requests' notification center.

Would be feasible to have this kind of notifications in the 'My pull requests' notification center on Stash dashboard.
fields.summary: Add 'Declined' Pull Requests in 'My pull requests' notification center

fields.description:
a repeating scenario in Pull Request review:

1. reviewer finds & comments on problem (comment visible in Overview)
2. author fixes problem (commit visible in Overview)

this scenario is ok, the problem arises when there are a lot of comments on problems spread out across the work being reviewed.
when the author starts fixing stuff, it is hard to keep track of what was fixed and if it was fixed appropriately.

i noticed that reviewer's comments are marked outdated.

it would be a great help if not only they are marked outdated, but the author's commit item in the Overview also contains a list of which comments are outdated by that commit

bonus:
each outdated comment in the list also has snippets of code before and after the commit.
fields.summary: Pull Request commit update lists outdated comments with before & after snippets

fields.description: Currently Stash uses the display name of the user, which is the normal convention of Git (at least for open source). For customers who use the 'username' instead it is jarring to have Stash use the display name just for the pull request merges, and a system to change this behaviour would be nice.
fields.summary: Allow pull request merge author name to be configurable as username

fields.description: When creating a branch via JIRA and Stash it would be great to have a Checkbox on the Create Branch Page to checkout the branch directly after clicking on the Create Button. This would make the workflow a little bit more intuitive.
fields.summary: Checkout Branch directly after creating it

fields.description:
I have some GIT repositories currently managed with gitolite that I would like to move over to stash, so that I can leverage the much tighter integration with JIRA.

However, what currently blocks me doing that is the fact that the current "Advanced Branch Permissions" are not advanced at all.

E.g. what I specifically miss is the following:
# one or more regular expressions to define allowed branch names being pushed
# one or more regular expressions to define allowed tag names being pushed
# disable deletion of certain branches
# disable non-fast-forwards for certain branches
# disable merge-commits on certain branches

\\
All the above I already have implemented with gitolite, which implements a big part to make sure that the day-to-day development work is not disturbed and accidental pushes are technically prevented.
fields.summary: Branch permissions control

fields.description: In pull requests we often want to @ notify a team (usually a CC/FYI type mention) rather than a specific user.
fields.summary: Ability to @-mention a group

fields.description:
It would be beneficial to allow customers to incrementally migrate portions of their Stash instance to a new instance along project or repository lines.

This is particularly important in multi-team setups where big-bang migrations may be operationally difficult.
fields.summary: Support proj-by-proj and repo-by-repo migration to new Stash instances

fields.description:
Related plugin:
https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.madgnome.stash.plugins.buccaneer

However, the plugin:
1. doesn't work (seems abandoned)
2. is designed only for Source view, not for Pull Request Diff view

This would greatly improve code review: If I'm inspecting a piece of code and encounter a method call of a method which implementation I wish to inspect, I just click on the method name in the method call and I'm taken to the method implementation (or a list of locations where the method might be is suggested).
Analogous behavior for types (classes or whatever).

Also: If the location is in the Diff list, the link lead out of the Diff view.
fields.summary: Pull Request Diff source links to implementations of types & methods
